description: The objective of this course is to study the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. This course serves as an extension of FNCE 100. Some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics. Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203. These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy.
name: ADVANCED CORP FINANCE

values.comments:
The objective of this course is to study the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. Serving as a complement and supplement to FNCE 100, FNCE 203 covers some of the FNCE 100 material more in-depth and more rigorously and also introduces some areas of financial management not previously covered, including leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics.

 Reviews for this course were mixed, but tended to be negative. While one student wrote that it was a “valuable class due to the importance of concepts taught and many case studies,” almost all criticized “the arbitrary and unexplained grading.” Some criticized the undergraduate TA’s as unable to “evaluate complex subjective assignments.” While described as having “a very dry style of teaching,” Professor Kihlstrom was also praised as “a very nice man and generally helpful.” 

Students’ main issue with the course was with the perceived lack of grading consistency and lack of feedback. “This course had great potential,” one student summarized, “but was set up in a poor way.” This review is based on the eight student comments that were submitted.
